title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics
text:
Let’s use read_csv function of readr package to load the data from Exam_data.csv into R.

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics
text:
2.1 Examination scores distribution
Let’s create boxplots for the performance of 3 subjects and arrange them in a row for easy comparison.

library("ggpubr")
boxplt1 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,   
  aes(y = MATHS)) +   
  geom_boxplot() 
boxplt2 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,   
  aes(y = ENGLISH)) +   
  geom_boxplot()
boxplt3 <- ggplot(data = exam_data,   
  aes(y = SCIENCE)) +   
  geom_boxplot()
ggarrange(boxplt1, boxplt2, boxplt3, ncol = 3, nrow = 1)










Observation



Students did better in Maths as compared to English and Science. There are some outliers in Maths and English boxplots where students did very poorly.


Let’s dive a little deeper to see how each class performs.

ggplot(data = exam_data,   
  aes(x = CLASS, y = MATHS)) +   
  geom_boxplot()+
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour = "red",        
               size = 3) 



ggplot(data = exam_data,   
  aes(x = CLASS, y = ENGLISH)) +   
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour = "red",        
               size = 3) 



ggplot(data = exam_data,   
  aes(x = CLASS, y = SCIENCE)) +   
  geom_boxplot() +
  stat_summary(geom = "point",       
               fun = "mean",         
               colour = "red",        
               size = 3) 










Observations




There are 9 classes in this dataset.
Students from Class 3I have poorer performance in all 3 subjects (many failed 3 subjects), whereas students from Class 3A have better performance in all 3 subjects.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics
text:
2.2 Race distribution
Let’s take a look at the students’ race distribution:

ggplot(data = exam_data, 
       aes(x = fct_infreq(RACE))) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title="Distribution of race",
       x = "Race",
       y = "Number of students") + 
  ylim(0, 210) +
  geom_text(aes(label = after_stat(count)), 
            stat = "count", vjust = -0.5, colour = "brown")










Observation



From the bar chart above, the majority of the students are Chinese, followed by Malay.


What about the race distribution in each class?

ggplot(data = exam_data) +
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x =CLASS, fill = RACE))










Observations




Class 3A has more Chinese students whereas Class 3I has more Malay students.
Class 3I has the fewest number of students.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics
text:
2.3 Gender distribution
Let’s take a look at the students’ gender distribution:

ggplot(data = exam_data, 
       aes(x = fct_infreq(GENDER))) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(title="Distribution of gender",
       x = "Gender",
       y = "Number of students") + 
  ylim(0, 210) +
  geom_text(aes(label = after_stat(count)), 
            stat = "count", vjust = -0.5, colour = "brown")










Observation



There are more female students than male students.


What about the distribution of gender in each class?

ggplot(data = exam_data) +
  geom_bar(mapping = aes(x =CLASS, fill = GENDER))










Observation



There are more female students in Class 3B and fewer female students in Class 3I.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1: A Layered Grammar of Graphics
section: 2.4 Correlation between performances of different subjects
text:
2.4 Correlation between performances of different subjects
Let’s see if there is any correlation between the performance of Maths vs English, Maths vs Science, and English vs Science via scatter plots.

ggplot(data=exam_data,
  aes(x = MATHS,y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(linewidth = 0.5) +
  # use the same axis range
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))



ggplot(data=exam_data,
  aes(x = MATHS,y = SCIENCE)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(linewidth = 0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))



ggplot(data=exam_data,
  aes(x = ENGLISH, y = SCIENCE)) +
  geom_point() + 
  geom_smooth(linewidth = 0.5) +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))










Observations



All 3 scatter plots show some positive correlation between the performances of the subjects. However, we would need to calculate the correlation coefficients to determine how strong the correlations are.

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text: In this exercise, we are using ggplot2 extensions to create more elegant and effective statistical graphics using ggrepel, ggthemes, hrbrthemes, and patchwork packages.

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
section: 2.1 Installing and launching the required libraries
text:
2.1 Installing and launching the required libraries
The code below uses p_load() of the Pacman package to check if all the following packages are installed on the laptop. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

tidyverse
ggrepel: an R package provides geoms for ggplot2 to repel overlapping text labels
ggthemes: an R package provides some extra themes, geoms, and scales for ‘ggplot2’.
hrbrthemes: an R package provides typography-centric themes and theme components for ggplot2.
patchwork: an R package for preparing composite figures created using ggplot2.


pacman::p_load(tidyverse, ggrepel,
               ggthemes, hrbrthemes,
               patchwork)

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
2.2 Importing the data
Exam_data consists of year-end examination grades of a cohort of primary 3 students from a local school. It is in the CSV file format.
The code chunk below imports exam_data.csv into the R environment by using read_csv() function of the readr package (one of the tidyverse packages).

exam_data <- read_csv("data/Exam_data.csv")







Observations




This data is about students’ examination scores for their 3 subjects (English, Maths, and Science) from various classes in Primary 3 from a school.
There are 4 categorical variables: ID, CLASS, GENDER, and RACE, and 3 continuous variables: ENGLISH, MATHS, and SCIENCE.
Out of the 3 subjects, Maths has the higher mean and median score.

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
3.1 Working with ggrepel
Let’s replace geom_label() by geom_label_repel().

ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS, y = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method = lm, size = 0.5) +
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
              fontface = "bold") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim = c(0, 100), 
                  ylim = c(0, 100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths score for Primary 3 students")










Observation



Though the plot is neater, the annotation appears only at some data points as many points are overlapped. There is an option to increase max.overlaps.

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
4.1 Working with ggtheme package
ggthemes provides ‘ggplot2’ themes that replicate the look of plots by Edward Tufte, Stephen Few, Fivethirtyeight, The Economist, ‘Stata’, ‘Excel’, and The Wall Street Journal, among others.
Check out some of the available themes here:

EconomistExcelFewSolarized



ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100,
                  color = "grey25", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores (Economist theme)") +
  theme_economist()







ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100,
                  color = "grey25", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores (Excel theme)") +
  theme_excel()







ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100,
                  color = "grey25", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores (Few theme)") +
  theme_few()







ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 20, boundary = 100,
                  color = "grey25", fill = "grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores (Solarized theme)") +
  theme_solarized()

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
4.2 Working with hrbrthemes package
hrbrthemes package provides a base theme that focuses on typographic elements, including where various labels are placed as well as the fonts that are used.

ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, boundary = 100,
                  color="grey25", fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum()




The second goal centers around productivity for a production workflow. This “production workflow” is the context for where the elements of hrbrthemes should be used. Consult this vignette to learn more.

ggplot(data = exam_data, aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, boundary = 100,
                  color="grey25", fill="grey90") +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores") +
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 20, 
              base_size = 15, grid = "Y")










Attributes in the theme_ipsum() function




axis_title_size is used to increase the font size of the axis title to 20
base_size is used to increase the default axis label to 15
grid = "Y" is used to remove the x-axis grid lines. If set to “X”, y-axis grid lines will be removed.

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
5.1 Creating composite graphics: pathwork methods
One ggplot2 extension we are exploring in this section is patchwork.
The patchwork package has a very simple syntax where we can create layouts easily.

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
5.2 Combining two ggplot2 graphs
Simply use + to combine 2 plots in a two-column layout!

p1 + p2

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
text:
5.3 Combining three ggplot2 graphs
We can plot more complex composite by using appropriate operators. For example, the composite figure below is plotted by using:

“|” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs,
“/” operator to place the plots beside each other,
“()” operator to define the sequence of the plotting.


Layout 1Layout 2Layout 3



(p1 / p2) | p3







(p1 | p2) / p3







p1 | p2 | p3

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
section: 5.4 Creating a composite figure with tag
text:
5.4 Creating a composite figure with tag
In order to identify subplots in text, patchwork also provides auto-tagging capabilities as shown in the figure below.

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')

title: Hands-on Exercise 2: Beyond ggplot2 Fundamentals
section: 5.5 Creating a composite figure with an insert
text:
5.5 Creating a composite figure with an insert
With inset_element() of patchwork, we can place one or several plots or graphic elements freely on top or below another plot.

p3 + inset_element(p2,
  left = 0.02,
  bottom = 0.7,
  right = 0.5,
  top = 1)

section: 5.6 Creating a composite figure by using patchwork and ggtheme
text:
5.6 Creating a composite figure by using patchwork and ggtheme

Apply theme to all plotsApply theme to a single plot



patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()







(p1 / p2) | (p3 + theme_economist())
